subject: OS-7261 Want a more modern nawk(1) Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com> Approved by: Jason King <jbk@joyent.com>
commitMessage:
OS-7261 Want a more modern nawk(1)
Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com>
Approved by: Jason King <jbk@joyent.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 4:

This update represents a lot of different changes in functionality. The OS-7261 summary contains a list of changes from the FIXES file that are in this change. I've tried to break them up into individual commits to make it easier to see what was needed for each change:

https://github.com/melloc/illumos-gate/commits/awk-update

The changes from patchset 3 to patchset 4 are some additional tests I have written that I haven't yet tried to upstream.

Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

I'm not sure if my review is as thorough as I'd like, but at least this is something.

Patch Set 5:

(5 comments)

The updates are in PS5, so you can see them with:

https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/4947/4..5

PS6 is a rebase.

Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

In addition to adding the comment, I've also fixed a separate issue I noticed with initializing the "fields" array.

Patch Set 8:

I did some testing with RECSIZE=1 and UMEM_DEBUG=default (now added to runtests.sh at Robert's suggestion), and found some buffer overflow issues where space wasn't allocated for the final '\0'. (These were in places where I converted from using expand_buf() -> adjbuf(), but didn't adjust the size to include "+ 1"; expand_buf() always made sure to allocate space for a trailing '\0'.)
Uploaded patch set 9: Patch Set 8 was rebased.
Uploaded patch set 10: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 11:

Nothing changed in patchset 11 aside from fixing a rebasing issue.
Uploaded patch set 12: Patch Set 11 was rebased.
Change has been successfully merged by Cody Peter Mello
I guess this doesn't care if one of the digits isn't a valid hex digit. I guess that's intentional?

It uses isxdigit(*p) to stop at the first non-hex digit. This allows writing the following programs:

    % gawk 'BEGIN { print ("kr" ~ /^\x6br$/); print ("\nq" ~ /^\xaq$/); }'
    1
    1
    % mawk 'BEGIN { print ("kr" ~ /^\x6br$/); print ("\nq" ~ /^\xaq$/); }'
    1
    1
    % /usr/bin/nawk 'BEGIN { print ("kr" ~ /^\x6br$/); print ("\nq" ~ /^\xaq$/); }' 
    0
    0
    % /home/cody/ws/smartos-live/projects/illumos/usr/src/cmd/awk/nawk 'BEGIN { print ("kr" ~ /^\x6br$/); print ("\nq" ~ /^\xaq$/); }'
    1
    1

This makes the behaviour the same as what /usr/bin/nawk currently does for strings:

    % gawk 'BEGIN { printf("\x6br\xaq"); }' | od -t a
    0000000   k   r  lf   q
    0000004
    % mawk 'BEGIN { printf("\x6br\xaq"); }' | od -t a
    0000000   k   r  lf   q
    0000004
    % /home/cody/ws/smartos-live/projects/illumos/usr/src/cmd/awk/nawk 'BEGIN { printf("\x6br\xaq"); }' | od -t a
    0000000   k   r  lf   q
    0000004
    % /usr/bin/nawk 'BEGIN { printf("\x6br\xaq"); }' | od -t a 
    0000000   k   r  lf   q
    0000004
I've changed it to use the tostring() helper function, which checks for allocation failures.
Extraneous blank here and lots of other places.
I assume all this changed because we fixed bugs in NF handling?
Yes, this is from "Aug 23, 2018: Decrementing NF did not change $0". The new nawk, mawk and gawk now all produce the same output for the t.NF script.
Was this something added from upstream?

No, this is a fix I made. It used to be "i = 0", but that then allows writing a '\0' into the buffer for [[:cntrl:]], since iscntrl(0) is true. I changed i to 1, and added the message above. In order for nawk to support matching NUL characters (which some implementations like gawk and mawk do support), the whole program would need to be adapted to pass the length of each string around.
OK. Can you please expand the comment? I'd suggest you use something like what you have above as it's a pretty clear explanation of what's going on.
Do we need LD_PRELOAD to make sure that umem is actually linked against?

It's not necessary, since I added -lumem to the Makefile, so the binary produced by the gate will use it.

I did try running with LD_PRELOAD=/usr/lib/libumem.so set in the environment, and found that it caused issues with ksh93, since they were 64-bit processes and needed /usr/lib/amd64/libumem.so. Setting it to the latter doesn't work either, since awk and some of the commands it runs are 32-bit processes.

OK, that's good to know. It may be worth a comment. For future reference there are a few ways to deal with that. The best is to just not specify an actual path, as in, LD_PRELOAD=libumem.so. Otherwise there are env vars specific for 32-bit and 64-bit applications ala LD_PRELOAD_32 and LD_PRELOAD_64.
